steps.heading: base.html
steps.code:
{{ title }}

{{ message }}

{% block content %} {% endblock %}

steps.heading: home.html

{% extends "base.html" %} {% block content %} {% for student in students %} {% endfor %}
ID Name Course
{{ student["ID"] }} {{ student["Name"] }} {{ student["Course"] }}
{% endblock %}

steps.heading: app.py
steps.code:
from jinja2 import Environment, FileSystemLoader, select_autoescape
import os

BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))

env = Environment(
    loader=FileSystemLoader(os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "templates")),
    autoescape=select_autoescape(["html", "xml"])
)


def app(environ, start_response):
    path = environ.get("PATH_INFO", "/")

    students = [
        {"ID": 1, "Name": "Alice Johnson", "Course": "Computer Science"},
        {"ID": 2, "Name": "Brian Smith", "Course": "Information Technology"},
        {"ID": 3, "Name": "Catherine Lee", "Course": "Business Administration"},
        {"ID": 4, "Name": "David Brown", "Course": "Mechanical Engineering"},
        {"ID": 5, "Name": "Emma Wilson", "Course": "Psychology"},
        {"ID": 6, "Name": "Frank Garcia", "Course": "Electrical Engineering"},
        {"ID": 7, "Name": "Grace Martinez", "Course": "Marketing"},
        {"ID": 8, "Name": "Henry Anderson", "Course": "Civil Engineering"},
        {"ID": 9, "Name": "Isabella Thomas", "Course": "Biology"},
        {"ID": 10, "Name": "James Taylor", "Course": "Accounting"}
    ]

    if path.endswith("/students"):
        title = "Students List"
        message = "Dynamic Table with Jinja2"
    else:
        title = "Home"
        message = "Plain Python + Gunicorn + Jinja2"

    template = env.get_template("home.html")
    html = template.render(title=title, message=message, students=students)

    start_response("200 OK", [("Content-Type", "text/html; charset=utf-8")])
    return [html.encode("utf-8")]

steps.heading: app.py
steps.code:
from jinja2 import Environment, FileSystemLoader
import os

BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))

env = Environment(
    loader=FileSystemLoader(os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "templates")),
    autoescape=True
)

def app(environ, start_response):
    path = environ.get("PATH_INFO", "/")

    if path.endswith("/hello"):
        title = "Hello Page"
        message = "Rendered using Jinja2"
    else:
        title = "Home"
        message = "Plain Python + Gunicorn + Nginx"

    template = env.get_template("home.html")
    html = template.render(title=title, message=message)

    start_response("200 OK", [("Content-Type", "text/html; charset=utf-8")])
    return [html.encode("utf-8")]

title: App1
description: Build a plain Python WSGI app using Jinja2 and Gunicorn inside a virtual environment

steps.heading: Go to Home Directory
steps.explanation: Start by navigating to your home directory.
steps.code: cd ~

steps.heading: Copy the Virtual Environment
steps.explanation: Copy the preconfigured Python virtual environment to your home directory. This must be done first before activating.
steps.code: cp -r /opt/virt ~/

steps.heading: Activate the Virtual Environment
steps.explanation: Activate the virtual environment. You should see (virt) at the start of your prompt when activated.
steps.code:
source ~/virt/bin/activate

# You should see:
# (virt) username@server:~$

steps.heading: Create webapps Directory
steps.explanation: Create and navigate into the webapps directory where your applications will live.
steps.code:
mkdir webapps
cd webapps

steps.heading: Create app1 Directory
steps.explanation: Create and navigate into the app1 directory for this specific application.
steps.code:
mkdir app1
cd app1

steps.heading: Create Empty GitHub Repository and Clone It
steps.explanation: Create an empty repository on GitHub, then clone it. The 'empty repository' warning is expected and fine.
steps.code:
git clone git@github.com:xalhexi-sch/App1.git

# You may see:
# warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.
# This is expected and fine.

steps.heading: Create app.py
steps.explanation: Create the main application file using nano. This is a pure WSGI app using Jinja2 for templating. Save with Ctrl+O then Enter, exit with Ctrl+X.
steps.code:
nano app.py

# Paste this code:
from jinja2 import Environment, FileSystemLoader
import os

BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))

env = Environment(
    loader=FileSystemLoader(os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "templates")),
    autoescape=True
)

def app(environ, start_response):
    path = environ.get("PATH_INFO", "/")

    if path.endswith("/hello"):
        title = "Hello Page"
        message = "Rendered using Jinja2"
    else:
        title = "Home"
        message = "Plain Python + Gunicorn + Nginx"

    template = env.get_template("home.html")
    html = template.render(title=title, message=message)

    start_response("200 OK", [("Content-Type", "text/html; charset=utf-8")])
    return [html.encode("utf-8")]

steps.heading: Create Templates Folder and HTML File
steps.explanation: Create the templates directory and the home.html template file. This uses Jinja2 syntax with {{ variable }} placeholders.
steps.code:
mkdir templates cd templates nano home.html # Paste this HTML: {{ title }}

{{ title }}

{{ message }}

steps.heading: Return to App Root
steps.explanation: Navigate back to the app1 directory and verify your location with pwd.
steps.code:
cd ..
pwd

# Expected output:
# ~/webapps/app1

steps.heading: Run the App Using Gunicorn
steps.explanation: Start the application using Gunicorn. You can change the port (5000) if needed. The app:app refers to the app function inside app.py.
steps.code: gunicorn --bind 127.0.0.1:5000 app:app

steps.heading: Access the App
steps.explanation: Access your app through the server URL. The exact URL depends on your server/proxy setup.
steps.code:
# Example URL (depends on your server setup):
# http://172.17.100.15:9899/it21_banas/webapps/app1

# Final folder structure:
# webapps/
# ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ app1/
#     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.py
#     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/
#         ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ home.html

title: Git Basics: Create Repo & Push
description: Create a new repository, add files, commit changes, and push to GitHub

steps.heading: Create Project Folder
steps.explanation: Create a project folder and navigate into it. Use pwd to verify your location.
steps.code:
mkdir my-project
cd my-project

# Optional: check where you are
pwd

steps.heading: Initialize Git Repository
steps.explanation: Initialize Git in the folder and set the branch to 'main' (recommended).
steps.code:
git init

# Set branch to main
git branch -M main

steps.heading: Create Files
steps.explanation: Create a README file using nano. Save with Ctrl+O then Enter, exit with Ctrl+X. You can also create files quickly with echo.
steps.code:
# Create README with nano
nano README.md

# Or create file quickly
echo "Hello world" > hello.txt

# Check your files
ls

steps.heading: Check Status & Stage Files
steps.explanation: Check Git status to see untracked files, then add them to staging area.
steps.code:
git status

# Add all files
git add .

# Or add specific file
git add README.md

# Check status again
git status

steps.heading: Commit Changes
steps.explanation: Commit your staged changes with a descriptive message.
steps.code: git commit -m "Initial commit"

steps.heading: Create GitHub Repo & Connect
steps.explanation: On GitHub: Click 'New repository', name it, do NOT initialize with README. Copy the SSH link and connect your local repo.
steps.code:
# Add remote (replace USERNAME and my-project)
git remote add origin git@github.com:USERNAME/my-project.git

# Verify remote
git remote -v

steps.heading: Push to GitHub
steps.explanation: Push your commits to GitHub. The -u flag sets upstream, so future pushes only need 'git push'.
steps.code:
git push -u origin main

# Future pushes:
git push

steps.heading: Normal Workflow
steps.explanation: After initial setup, use this workflow when you make changes: status, add, commit, push.
steps.code:
git status
git add .
git commit -m "Describe what you changed"
git push

steps.heading: ~/run.sh
steps.explanation: ‚ö†Ô∏è CHANGE PORT
steps.code:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
cd ~/webapps/app4 || exit 1
source ~/virt/bin/activate

# stop old gunicorn on 5000 if any 
# PLEASE CHANGE YOUR PORT!
lsof -t -i :5000 | xargs -r kill

# start in background
nohup gunicorn --bind 127.0.0.1:5000 --workers 1 --timeout 120 app:app > ~/app4.log 2>&1 &
echo "App4 running. Log: ~/app4.log"

steps.heading: ~/stop.sh
steps.explanation: ‚ö†Ô∏è CHANGE PORT
steps.code:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
lsof -t -i :5000 | xargs -r kill
echo "app4 stopped"

# PLEASE CHANGE YOUR PORT HERE!

steps.heading: ~/run.sh
steps.code:
cd ~/webapps/app4

source ~/virt/bin/activate

gunicorn --bind 127.0.0.1:5065 app:app

steps.heading: chmod the script
steps.code:
chmod +x ~/run.sh
chmod +x ~/stop.sh

steps.heading: Create a Branch
steps.explanation: Create and switch to a new branch.
steps.code: git checkout -b feature-name

steps.heading: Switch Branches
steps.explanation: Move between different branches.
steps.code: git checkout main

steps.heading: Merge Branch
steps.explanation: Combine changes from another branch.
steps.code: git merge feature-name

title: SSH Connection
description: Connect to the ITP server via SSH

steps.heading: Basic SSH Command
steps.explanation: Connect to the server using your credentials.

steps.heading: First Time Setup
steps.explanation: Accept the fingerprint when prompted.
steps.code: # Type 'yes' when asked about authenticity

title: Getting Started with Git
description: Learn the basics of version control with Git

steps.heading: Initialize a Repository
steps.explanation: Create a new Git repository in your project folder.
steps.code: git init

steps.heading: Check Status
steps.explanation: See which files have been modified or staged.
steps.code: git status

steps.heading: Stage Changes
steps.explanation: Add files to staging area before committing.
steps.code: git add .

steps.heading: Commit Changes
steps.explanation: Save your staged changes with a descriptive message.
steps.code: git commit -m "Your message"

title: SSH + GitHub SSH Setup (ed25519)
description: Complete guide to SSH into server, generate ed25519 keys, configure GitHub SSH with Port 443, and set up Git

steps.heading: Connect to the Server
steps.explanation: Open Terminal and SSH into your school server. When prompted, type 'yes' if asked to continue connecting, then enter your password.

steps.heading: Switch to Bash (Optional)
steps.explanation: Switch to bash shell for better compatibility. This step is optional but recommended.
steps.code: bash

steps.heading: Create .ssh Folder
steps.explanation: Create the .ssh directory if it doesn't exist and navigate into it. You can verify your location with pwd.
steps.code:
mkdir -p ~/.ssh
cd ~/.ssh

# Optional: verify directory
pwd

steps.heading: Generate SSH Key (ed25519)
steps.explanation: Generate a new SSH key using the ed25519 algorithm. Press Enter for default file location, and Enter again for no passphrase (or set one if you prefer).
steps.code: ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

steps.heading: Show and Copy Public Key
steps.explanation: Display your public key and copy the entire output (starts with 'ssh-ed25519'). You'll need this for GitHub.
steps.code: cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

steps.heading: Add Public Key to GitHub
steps.explanation: On GitHub: Go to Settings > SSH and GPG keys > New SSH key. Give it a title like 'School Server Key', paste your public key, and click 'Add SSH key'.
steps.code:
# No terminal command needed
# 1. Go to GitHub Settings
# 2. Click 'SSH and GPG keys'
# 3. Click 'New SSH key'
# 4. Title: School Server Key
# 5. Paste your public key
# 6. Click 'Add SSH key'

steps.heading: Configure SSH for Port 443
steps.explanation: Create/edit the SSH config file to force GitHub SSH connections through Port 443. This bypasses firewall restrictions. Use Ctrl+O then Enter to save, and Ctrl+X to exit nano.
steps.code:
nano ~/.ssh/config

# Paste this content:
Host github.com
  HostName ssh.github.com
  User git
  Port 443
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

steps.heading: Fix SSH Permissions
steps.explanation: Set the correct permissions for your SSH files. This is important for security and proper SSH operation.
steps.code:
chmod 700 ~/.ssh
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/config
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

steps.heading: Set Git Global Config
steps.explanation: Configure Git with your name and email so your commits are properly attributed. Optionally set 'main' as your default branch.
steps.code:
git config --global user.name "Your Full Name"
git config --global user.email "your_email@example.com"

# Optional: set default branch to main
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

# Optional: verify your config
git config --global --list

steps.heading: Verify GitHub SSH Connection
steps.explanation: Test your SSH connection to GitHub. If successful, you'll see a message like 'Hi USERNAME! You've successfully authenticated...' Type 'yes' if asked to trust the host.
steps.code: ssh -T git@github.com

steps.heading: Return Home and Exit
steps.explanation: Navigate back to your home directory and exit the server when you're done. Remember: never share your private key (id_ed25519), only share the public key (id_ed25519.pub).
steps.code:
cd ~
pwd  # Optional: confirm location

# When done, exit the server
exit

title: Clone Existing Repo from GitHub
description: How to clone an existing repository and start working on it

steps.heading: Navigate to Projects Folder
steps.explanation: Go to the folder where you want the repo to be downloaded. Create a projects folder if needed.
steps.code:
# Go to home directory
cd ~

# Or create a projects folder
mkdir -p ~/projects
cd ~/projects

steps.heading: Clone the Repository
steps.explanation: Copy the SSH link from GitHub and clone the repo. This creates a folder with the repo name.
steps.code:
# Clone using SSH (recommended)
git clone git@github.com:USERNAME/REPO_NAME.git

# Example:
git clone git@github.com:octocat/Hello-World.git

steps.heading: Enter & Verify
steps.explanation: Enter the cloned repo folder and verify the remote and branch.
steps.code:
cd REPO_NAME

# Check remote
git remote -v

# Check branch
git branch

steps.heading: Make Changes & Push
steps.explanation: Create or edit files, then stage, commit, and push your changes.
steps.code:
# Create/edit a file
nano notes.txt

# Stage, commit, push
git add .
git commit -m "Add notes"
git push

steps.heading: Useful Commands
steps.explanation: Handy commands for checking history, changes, and syncing with remote.
steps.code:
# Check commit history
git log --oneline

# See file changes
git diff

# Pull latest updates
git pull

# Check current branch
git branch

title: Ubuntu: Rename & Move Files
description: How to rename files and move them between folders in Ubuntu

steps.heading: Rename a File
steps.explanation: Use mv command to rename files. Same syntax works for folders.
steps.code:
# Rename a file
mv oldname.txt newname.txt

# Example
mv notes.txt notes-final.txt

# Rename a folder
mv oldfolder newfolder

steps.heading: Move File to Parent Folder
steps.explanation: Use ../ to reference the parent folder. Move files one level up with mv.
steps.code:
# Move file one level up
mv file.txt ../

# Move folder one level up
mv myfolder ../

# Move multiple files up
mv a.txt b.txt c.txt ../

steps.heading: Move Multiple Levels Up
steps.explanation: Use multiple ../ to go up several levels. Each ../ goes up one folder.
steps.code:
# ../ = up 1 folder
# ../../ = up 2 folders
# ../../../ = up 3 folders

# Move file up 2 levels
mv file.txt ../../

steps.heading: Move File Into Another Folder
steps.explanation: Move a file into a subfolder by specifying the folder name.
steps.code:
mv file.txt foldername/

# Example
mv hello.txt src/

steps.heading: Check Location & List Files
steps.explanation: Helpful commands to see where you are and what files exist.
steps.code:
# Print working directory
pwd

# List files
ls

# List all files with details
ls -la

title: Check GitHub Repo Contributors
description: Three ways to check contributors of a GitHub repository

steps.heading: GitHub Web (Easiest)
steps.explanation: The simplest way - use the GitHub website to view contributors.
steps.code:
# No terminal needed
# On the repo page:
# 1. Click 'Insights' tab
# 2. Click 'Contributors' in sidebar

steps.heading: Using Git Log
steps.explanation: Use git shortlog to see contributors and their commit counts. Works without GitHub CLI.
steps.code:
# Inside the repo folder:
git shortlog -s -n

# -s = show commit counts only
# -n = sort by number of commits

# Show names + emails:
git shortlog -sne

steps.heading: Install GitHub CLI
steps.explanation: Install the GitHub CLI (gh) if not already installed, then login.
steps.code:
# Check if installed
gh --version

# Install on Ubuntu
sudo apt update
sudo apt install gh -y

# Login to GitHub
gh auth login

steps.heading: Using GitHub CLI
steps.explanation: Use gh api to fetch contributor data. Works for public repos or repos you have access to.
steps.code:
# Get contributors
gh api repos/OWNER/REPO/contributors

# Show only usernames
gh api repos/OWNER/REPO/contributors --jq '.[].login'

# Show username + contributions
gh api repos/OWNER/REPO/contributors --jq '.[] | "\(.login) - \(.contributions)"'

steps.heading: Quick Tip for Screenshots
steps.explanation: If you need screenshot proof for a teacher, this command clearly shows contributors with commit counts.
steps.code: git shortlog -sne

title: Common Git Errors & Fixes
description: Quick fixes for common Git errors you might encounter

steps.heading: Permission Denied (publickey)
steps.explanation: This error means your SSH key is not set up or not added to GitHub.
steps.code:
# Test SSH connection
ssh -T git@github.com

# If it fails, check your SSH key setup
# Refer to the SSH + GitHub Setup tutorial

steps.heading: Remote Origin Already Exists
steps.explanation: Remove the existing remote and add it again with the correct URL.
steps.code:
# Remove existing remote
git remote remove origin

# Add new remote
git remote add origin git@github.com:USERNAME/REPO_NAME.git

steps.heading: Branch is Master Instead of Main
steps.explanation: Rename your local branch to main and push to the main branch.
steps.code:
# Rename branch to main
git branch -M main

# Push to main
git push -u origin main

title: Setting Up Web Terminal (Admin)
description: How to install and configure ttyd for web-based terminal access

steps.heading: Install ttyd on your VPS
steps.explanation: SSH into your VPS and install ttyd. This tool exposes a terminal session as a web page.
steps.code:
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt update
sudo apt install ttyd

# Check version
ttyd --version

steps.heading: Kill existing ttyd process (if running)
steps.explanation: Before starting ttyd, make sure no other instance is using the port.
steps.code:
# Kill any running ttyd
pkill ttyd

# Or find and kill manually
ps aux | grep ttyd
kill <PID>

steps.heading: Generate SSL Certificate (REQUIRED for HTTPS sites)
steps.explanation: Vercel uses HTTPS. Browsers block HTTP iframes in HTTPS pages. You MUST use SSL for embedding to work.
steps.code:
# Generate self-signed certificate
openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 \
  -keyout /root/ttyd-key.pem \
  -out /root/ttyd-cert.pem \
  -subj '/CN=localhost'

# Or use Let's Encrypt for a real domain (recommended)

steps.heading: Run ttyd with SSL
steps.explanation: Start ttyd with SSL enabled and the -O flag to allow iframe embedding.
steps.code:
# Run with SSL (REQUIRED for Vercel embedding)
ttyd -W -p 7681 -O \
  --ssl \
  --ssl-cert /root/ttyd-cert.pem \
  --ssl-key /root/ttyd-key.pem \
  bash

# Run in background
nohup ttyd -W -p 7681 -O --ssl --ssl-cert /root/ttyd-cert.pem --ssl-key /root/ttyd-key.pem bash &

steps.heading: With Authentication (Recommended)
steps.explanation: Add username/password protection to prevent unauthorized access.
steps.code:
# With SSL + authentication
ttyd -W -p 7681 -O \
  --ssl \
  --ssl-cert /root/ttyd-cert.pem \
  --ssl-key /root/ttyd-key.pem \
  -c student:practice123 \
  bash

steps.heading: Configure Firewall
steps.explanation: Open the port on your VPS firewall.
steps.code:
# UFW (Ubuntu)
sudo ufw allow 7681

# Or iptables
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 7681 -j ACCEPT

steps.heading: Test and Get Your URL
steps.explanation: First visit the URL directly in browser and accept the self-signed certificate warning. Then use this HTTPS URL in admin Terminal Settings.
steps.code:
# Your terminal URL (MUST be HTTPS):
https://YOUR_VPS_IP:7681

# Example:
https://104.64.209.151:7681

# IMPORTANT: Visit this URL in browser first
# and click 'Advanced' -> 'Proceed' to accept
# the self-signed certificate!

steps.heading: PROMPT11
steps.code:
**PROMPT 1 (Desktop ‚ÄúWOW tutorial hub‚Äù ‚Äî closest to the image I sent):**
Create a high-resolution 2D UI mockup (clean, modern, premium SaaS style) of an educational website called ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial.‚Äù Show a desktop web app layout with a sticky top navigation bar and a left sidebar. Use a dark navy/blue header with subtle gradient, soft glow accents, rounded corners (16‚Äì20px), and gentle shadows. Top header elements (left to right): site title ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù, a centered search input with placeholder ‚ÄúSearch tutorials‚Ä¶‚Äù, a small ‚ÄúReport Issue‚Äù button/link, a ‚ÄúDark Mode‚Äù toggle icon, and a circular user avatar icon. Under the header, show a thin horizontal scroll progress bar that is partially filled. Left sidebar: grouped sections with headings and chevrons, each group separated by subtle dividers. Sidebar groups: ‚ÄúGit‚Äù with items ‚ÄúGit Basics‚Äù, ‚ÄúGit Branching‚Äù (active/selected), ‚ÄúGitHub Setup‚Äù, ‚ÄúCommon Git Errors‚Äù; ‚ÄúSSH & GitHub‚Äù with items ‚ÄúSSH Keys‚Äù, ‚ÄúGitHub SSH Access‚Äù; ‚ÄúLinux Commands‚Äù with items ‚ÄúUbuntu Commands‚Äù, ‚ÄúFile Permissions‚Äù; ‚ÄúWeb Apps‚Äù with item ‚ÄúPython Web App‚Äù. At the bottom of sidebar add ‚ÄúQuick Links‚Äù with items ‚ÄúITP GitHub‚Äù and ‚ÄúClass Resources.‚Äù The main content area: show breadcrumb near top ‚ÄúGit / Git Branching‚Äù. Large tutorial title: ‚ÄúGit Branching Basics‚Äù. Under the title show small pill tags: ‚ÄúBeginner‚Äù, ‚Äú10 mins‚Äù, ‚ÄúGit Guide‚Äù. Below, a short description sentence: ‚ÄúLearn how to create and manage branches in Git.‚Äù Then show stacked step cards (accordion style but expanded) with numbers and titles: ‚Äú1. Create a New Branch‚Äù, ‚Äú2. Switch to Your Branch‚Äù, ‚Äú3. Merge Branches‚Äù (third one partially visible). Each step card has a brief explanation line and a code block container. Code block has a small label ‚ÄúTerminal‚Äù on the left and a ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button on the right. Code examples: `git branch <branch-name>` and `git checkout <branch-name>`. On the right side of the main content area, show a slim info panel with heading ‚ÄúOn This Page‚Äù and checklist items ‚ÄúCreate Branch‚Äù, ‚ÄúCheckout Branch‚Äù, ‚ÄúMerge Branches‚Äù; below it a panel titled ‚ÄúExpected Output‚Äù showing: ‚ÄúSwitched to branch ‚Äòfeature-x‚Äô.‚Äù and another panel titled ‚ÄúCommon Issues‚Äù with a bullet: ‚ÄúError: Not a valid object name‚Äù and subtext ‚ÄúBranch name typo‚Äù. Bottom navigation: left button ‚ÄúPrevious‚Äù and right button ‚ÄúNext Tutorial ‚Üí‚Äù. Add a subtle abstract wave/gradient background at the bottom of the page (soft pastel blues/purples) and tiny particles for depth, but keep the UI readable. Use crisp typography, consistent spacing grid, and no real brand logos.
**SENTENCE:** Use this to generate a polished desktop UI screenshot mockup that matches the structure, labels, and vibe of the image.

---

**PROMPT 2 (Same layout, but with ‚Äúscroll reveal‚Äù vibe frozen in one frame):**
Design a high-resolution 2D UI mockup of the ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù web app in a premium modern style. Show the same header, sidebar, breadcrumb, title, tags, step cards, right info panels, and bottom navigation as a tutorial hub. Add subtle ‚Äúmotion cues‚Äù as static design elements: the active sidebar item ‚ÄúGit Branching‚Äù has a glowing pill highlight and a thin left accent bar; the step cards appear with faint drop shadows and slight upward offset shadows (as if they just slid into view). Add a subtle highlight ring around Step 2 to imply it is currently in focus. Include a thin top progress bar that is around 35‚Äì45% filled. Keep colors clean: navy header, light main surface, soft gradients in accents. Make it look like a beautiful product screenshot (Dribbble style), sharp text, no blur.
**SENTENCE:** Use this when you want the page to *feel animated* even though it‚Äôs a still image.

---

**PROMPT 3 (Click interaction moment ‚Äî ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù success state):**
Create a premium 2D UI mockup of the ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù page for ‚ÄúGit Branching Basics‚Äù (same layout: top header, left sidebar, main content with step cards, right info panels). Focus on the micro-interaction: show the ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button on Step 1 in its clicked success state. The button label should read ‚ÄúCopied ‚úì‚Äù with a subtle green/teal confirmation accent, and the code block border should have a brief glowing outline to indicate success. Add a small toast notification in the top-right of the content area: ‚ÄúCopied to clipboard‚Äù with a check icon. Keep everything clean and minimal, with rounded corners, soft shadows, and consistent spacing.
**SENTENCE:** Use this to visualize the satisfying ‚ÄúCopied!‚Äù feedback moment.

---

**PROMPT 4 (Accordion interaction ‚Äî Step 2 expands smoothly):**
Generate a high-resolution 2D UI mockup of ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù where Step 2 is expanded and Step 1 is collapsed in accordion style. Same sidebar groups and header elements. Step 1 shows only its title row and a small chevron icon pointing down; Step 2 shows full content: explanation text + code block with ‚ÄúTerminal‚Äù label + ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button; Step 3 is collapsed. Add subtle divider lines and gentle shadows. Make the expanded card feel ‚Äúactive‚Äù with slightly stronger shadow and a thin accent border.
**SENTENCE:** Use this to preview how your step cards look when users expand/collapse them.

---

**PROMPT 5 (Sidebar + scrollspy emphasis):**
Design a sleek educational web app mockup titled ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial.‚Äù Keep the same structure, but emphasize scrollspy: the sidebar highlights ‚ÄúGit Branching‚Äù as active, and within the right ‚ÄúOn This Page‚Äù panel, the item ‚ÄúCheckout Branch‚Äù is highlighted as the current section (slightly darker background pill). Show Step 2 visually emphasized as the active step. Add a subtle vertical progress indicator in the ‚ÄúOn This Page‚Äù list to imply reading progress. Maintain a premium minimal style with rounded corners and soft shadows.
**SENTENCE:** Use this to visualize the ‚Äúit follows me as I scroll‚Äù navigation feel.

**PROMPT 6 (Mobile version ‚Äî drawer sidebar + sticky actions):**
Create a high-resolution mobile UI mockup (phone screen) of ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial.‚Äù Use a sticky top bar with the title and a search icon, plus a hamburger menu icon that opens a left drawer. Show the drawer open with the same grouped sidebar items: Git, SSH & GitHub, Linux Commands, Web Apps, Quick Links. Main content shows ‚ÄúGit Branching Basics‚Äù with tags (Beginner, 10 mins), and Step cards stacked vertically with code blocks and Copy buttons. Add a bottom sticky action bar with ‚ÄúPrevious‚Äù and ‚ÄúNext‚Äù buttons. Clean modern style, rounded cards, readable typography, no clutter.
**SENTENCE:** Use this to preview how the same tutorial experience looks on mobile.

---

**PROMPT 7 (Dark mode ‚ÄúWOW‚Äù theme):**
Generate a premium dark-mode 2D UI mockup of the ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù page. Keep the exact same structure and text (header, sidebar groups, breadcrumb, ‚ÄúGit Branching Basics,‚Äù tags, step cards, right panels, bottom nav). Use dark charcoal surfaces with slightly lighter cards, neon-soft accent glows (blue/purple) for active states, and high contrast for code blocks. Copy buttons should be clear and accessible. Add a subtle animated-look gradient accent behind the header (but as a static image).
**SENTENCE:** Use this to visualize the ‚Äúsmooth hypnotic‚Äù dark-mode version.

---

**PROMPT 8 (Storyboards ‚Äî 4 panels showing the WOW moments):**
Create a 4-panel storyboard image (clean 2D UI mockups) showing the ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù website interactions. Panel 1: full desktop layout of ‚ÄúGit Branching Basics‚Äù with sidebar, header search, and step cards. Panel 2: mid-scroll state where Step 2 is in focus, sidebar scrollspy highlight updates, top progress bar is around 45%. Panel 3: user clicks Copy on a code block; show ‚ÄúCopied ‚úì‚Äù button state and a small toast ‚ÄúCopied to clipboard‚Äù. Panel 4: mobile view with hamburger drawer open and the same categories visible. Keep consistent branding (navy/blue accents, rounded corners, soft shadows), crisp text, no external logos.
**SENTENCE:** Use this to ‚Äúsee the animation‚Äù as a before/after set even in one image.

**PROMPT 9 (Ultra-premium ‚ÄúApple-like smooth‚Äù minimal variant):**
Design a super minimal, ultra-clean 2D UI mockup of ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù with lots of white space, thin dividers, subtle shadows, and restrained accents. Keep the same content and layout but simplify: smaller sidebar icons, soft gray surfaces, one accent color for active states, elegant typography. Code blocks look like refined developer docs with a top strip label ‚ÄúTerminal‚Äù and a compact Copy icon button. Right side panels are light and airy.

**PROMPT 10 (Component sheet ‚Äî so you can implement consistently):**
Create a UI component sheet for ‚ÄúITP Subject Tutorial‚Äù in a premium modern style. Show separate components on one canvas: top header bar with search field, sidebar group with active and inactive items, step card (collapsed + expanded), code block with Copy button (default + copied state), right panel card (‚ÄúOn This Page‚Äù), toast notification, primary/secondary buttons (‚ÄúPrevious‚Äù, ‚ÄúNext Tutorial‚Äù), tag pills (‚ÄúBeginner‚Äù, ‚Äú10 mins‚Äù). Keep consistent spacing, rounded corners, soft shadows, and a navy/blue accent palette.
**SENTENCE:** Use this to visualize the whole design system before you code anything.
